div.head: Summary
div.p: The United States recognized the People’s Republic of Mozambique on June 25, 1975, when President Gerald R. Ford sent a letter to that effect to President Samora Moises Machel.

div.head: U.S. Recognition of Mozambique, 1975.
div.p: The United States recognized the People’s Republic of Mozambique on June 25, 1975, when President Gerald R. Ford sent a letter to that effect to President Samora Moises Machel. Mozambique previously had been under Portuguese sovereignty.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations, 1975.
div.p: The United States and Mozambique established diplomatic relations on September 23, 1975, when Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Foreign Minister Joachim Alberto Chissano initialed a joint communiqué.

div.head: Establishment of the American Embassy in Mozambique, 1975.
div.p: Embassy Lourenco Marques (now Maputo) was opened on November 8, 1975, with Johnnie Carson as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim.
